Attention of the June Week Committee has turned to the alumni during the past few days, and an extensive effort is being made to bring
old Hopkins grads together for one
night during June Week festivities.
Saturday night, June 11, has been
set aside as alumni night, and a program that will bring joy to the
hearts of the Hopkins men of former years has been arranged. The
class of '23 will parade in their."old
and antique," delapidated headgear
and make merry as in former years.

ANOTHER INVITATION
Of what value is a college newspaper? Can a college weekly
or semi-weekly be worth anything (even the subscription price)
to the student who reads it? These questions have been worrying
us for quite a while, and whereas we are incapable of satisfactorily
answering them ourselves, we can at least analyze them and wait
for comments—constructive or non-constructive.
A semi-weekly of the type of the NEWS-LETTER attempts to
print news that pertains directly to the undergraduate body as
Hopkins students. It makes little effort to give detailed information concerning what is happening in other departments of the
University, not much more concerning the goings-on at other colleges, and none at all about topics not of a direct college nature.
Much of the news is stale by the time that it appears, and a portion of it is of interest only to certain men. It would be possible,
if the readers so desired, to publish more news of other Universities (or other departments of this University), but there has
been no articulate demand for such news.
The paper's editorial policy can be one of several varieties.
The editorials can shout "Hurrah"- and comment inanely upon
campus events, making an obsequious attempt to please everybody.
They can take issue with every question which lends itself to argument, and can invent a few besides. Or they can try to "mirror"
campus opinion—if there be such a thing. They can be a compromise between the first two policies, and, of course, they can be
a kind of conglomerate potpourri of all three.
They can attempt to evaluate the courses offered to the students, as has been done at Harvard. They can make an effort to
influence students in matters of a wider interest than pure "campus
topics." They can criticise activities and individuals in the campus
limelight—favorably or adversely. None of these have, to our
knowledge, been tried on this campus. The most weighty objection, it seems, is that the campus is so small that it is extremely
difficult (and undesirable, say some) to avoid the personal element
in conducting a campus newspaper. "
For the remainder of this year, we are inclined to evade the
issue, for it is too late to formulate a definite policy which could
bear fruit. To the extent that we sincerely desire to give the student body the type of newspaper that it wants (within limits—
financial and otherwise), we aim to please. Who knows that the
majority doesn't want any at all? We invite expressions of opinion on this subject, for we should like something to .think about
during the summer. Are we wasting much valuable time, or do
we or can we accomplish a certain amount of positive good?

A comparison of the 1926-27 catalogue of the College of Arts and
Sciences with the Faculty of Philosophy circular for 1927-28, just issued, drives home the change which
Dr. Frank J. Goodnow has instituted. Many courses, heretofore in the
Arts and Science Catalogue, are now
found in the pages of the Faculty of
Philosophy catalogue.
Botany and Bacteriolgy will be
offered by the Faculty of Philosophy. Vertebrate Zoology, formerly
offered to undergraduates, is now a
graduate course, given by Dr.
Cowles. Industrial Chemistry does
not find a place in the graduate
course catalogue. Chemistry has
taken a wholesale leap into the new
faculty of Philosophy circular with
such subjects as Quantitative Analysis, Advanced Inorganic Chemistry, Quantitative Chemistry, Chemical Thermodynamics transferred to
the New Plan scope of subjects.

and The Romantic Poets are to be

SIGMA TAU DELTA AND PHI
• PSI'S ADVANCES IN
BALL CONTESTS

DORM DOINGS

Two More Games Must Be Played To
A poor stray *dog has been addDetermine .Interfraternity
ed
to the collection of Dormitory
Semi-Finalists

Sigma Tau Delta and Phi Kappa Psi joined the ranks of the winners in the competition for the interfraternity baseball championship
The former fraternity won an exciting match from the Phi Gam's,
5-3, while the Phi Psi's have won
two games, by defeating the ,Beta's,
11-4; and the A. D.'s, 7-6.
.Kappa Sigma, also, not to be outdone, broke into the winning col
umn by beating the 0. K..0.'s, 5-4
Although Sigma Tau Delta scored four runs in the first inning of
a five inning game, it was only because of the relief pitching of Werner, who succeeded Driver in the final inning, that the Phi Gam's score
was kept down. The game was especially featured by the, work of
Werner, who proved to be a double threat man, his hitting being on
a par with his - pitching. McCauley,
who pitched for the losing team,
reached top form. after the first
inning, but the 'havoc wrought in
that session proved to be too great
a handicap.
Phi Psi's Win

In the struggle between the Beta's
and the Phi Psi's, baseball was
played amid wise-cracks, smoking
of cigarettes, errors, and amusing
situations. "Home Run" ,Brady,
after wonderful twirling for three
innings, in which he hit only three
batters, was relieved by Joe Richards. Averaging over three runs an
inning, the Phi Psi's did their best
to extend the four inning game to
darkness, and only failed by a matter of seconds. Campbell, the pitcher for the winners, held the losing
team scoreless until the last inning,
in which all the runs were made.
Brady received his title by knocking a screaming drive through the
legs of three fielders. In spite of
the score, the game proved to be
one of the most interesting of the
series.
Huey Pitches Well

In their game with the A. D.'s in
the second round, the Phi Psi's also
provided an interesting game. Huey,
who won his first gamt by striking
out twelve men, equaled his strikeout record, but lost a discouraging
game. The game which was planned to take five innings, lasted for
six sessions, as the score was tied
at the end of the- prescribed time.
Dukehart, a Phi Psi, who had caught
for the first few innings, came to
Campbell's rescue, and managed to
hold his rivals scoreless after the
fifth inning.
.The Phi Psi-A. D. game was the
opening clash in the second round
of competition.
Sigma Tau Delta tied with the
Phi Psis for the lead in the Interfraternity Baseball League by defeating Alpha Kappa Phi by the
score of 7-4 on Friday.

* * •*
The effect of the coming final
examinations can be readily observed among the residents. The
bridge games in the Commons
Room are shorter. Even the
most active residents seem
shrouded in gloom. These are
trying times at the Dorm.
* * *
Practically all of the rooms at
the Dormitory have been leased
for next year. In spite of all the
complaints which are •heard during the year everyone signs up
again for the following year.
Many residents who have lived at
the Dormitory for two or more
years live in an entry which is
kept as exclusive as a fraternity
house. It is interesting to note
that there are cases at the Dormitory where residents have practically lived alongside of one another for two or three years without even casually speaking. Such
is the jolly good fellowship

ambitious high school athletes.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE ITER. MAY 24, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
Two foremost collegiate authoriities on astronomy are engaged in
an amusing controversy concerning
the date of the final extinction of
the sun's light. Enrique E. Trevine, president of the Mexican Astronomical Society, recently published a report in which he predicts
that the sun will have ceased to
shine in 2,000,000 years. Professor
Edmund S. Manson, head of the department of Astronomy at Ohio
University, has definitely repudiated
Trevine's .statement, assuring us to
have no fear as the sun is sure to
be good yet for at least ten trillion
years.
• * * .
Startling disclosures were recently revealed in another sequel to the
"ask me another" craze—this time
among theseniors at Princeton University. The 'Most amusing, perhaps, was the manner in which the
young men vented their ire against
the sons of fair Harvard. That institution was most ironically selected after Smith and _Vassar as the
most popular women's college.
• * *
Freshman hazing at Ohio State
University will, it appears, die a sudden and inglorious death with the
close of this year. President George
W. Rightmire recently issued the
following statement:"Any man who
is in any way connected with throwing a freshman in the lake will sever
his connection with the university."
It may here be explained that the
aforesaid procedure was the favorite method of the eager sophs to
put a quietus on the unruliness of
their traditional foes.
*

*

*

Too much discipline in the modern college is severely flayed in a
recent verdict rendered by Walter
L. Whittlesey, professor of Politics,
at Princeton University. Dr. Whittlesey makes the sweeping statement
that neither Jefferson, Franklin,
Lincoln, nor Cleveland would submit to the restraint which is placed
on the student of today, but would
probably have been forced from college because of their independence.
*
*
Films of forty students representing most of the large colleges and
universities of the country have recently been selected by executives of
the First National Pictures, Inc., to
go into the finals of the "movie contest" which is being conducted by
that concern. Ten men, selected in
these finals, will be given an eight
week try-out in the First National
Movie School. From among these
ten those students that display promise will be tendered a five year contract at $75 a week for the first six
months, this gradually increasing
until in the fifth year they will receive $750 per week. Well, boys,
that's another advantage of higher
education.

CAMBRIDGE Al\D BRISTOL TO STUDY HERE
of Hearst Trophy
Announcement has been made
that two recent graduates of British
universities awarded Commonwealth
Fund fellowships are planning to
study at Johns Hopkins next year
Dr. Thomas F. Hewer, of the
University of Bristol, and John
Dennis Ward, of Cambridge University, are the successful candidates
planning to study here.
Twenty - three Commonwealth
Fund fellowships, amounting to
$125,000, were awarded to honor
graduates of universities in Great
Britain and her colonies this year.
The fund was established in 1918 by
the late Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness
as a philanthropic foundation "for
the welfare of mankind." Two
years ago the Board of Directors of
the foundation adopted the plan for
the British fellowships in the belief
that additional facilities for British
University graduates to study and

travel in this country would foster
the development of international
development and good will.
Any of the twenty-six institutions
belonging to the Association of
American Universities may be selected by the successful candidate.
In addition to Dr. Hewer and Mr.
Ward, two other Commonwealth
fellows are studying at Hopkins.
Dr. Hewer will do research work
in bacteriology while Mr. Ward will
study the "Attitude of the United
State.s toward British Relations with
Central America, 1850-1860."
So far more Commonwealth students have selected Harvard than
any other university in this country.
Ten have gone there, eight have selected. Yale, the same number Columbia, and six Cornell. Twentysix are attending other universities
all over the country.

ANOTHER INVITATION
Of what value is a college newspaper? Can a college weekly
or semi-weekly be worth anything (even the subscription price)
to the student who reads it? These questions have been worrying
us for quite a while, and whereas we are incapable of satisfactorily
answering them ourselves, we can at least analyze them and wait
for comments—constructive or non-constructive.
A semi-weekly of the type of the NEWS-LETTER attempts to
print news that pertains directly to the undergraduate body as
Hopkins students. It makes little effort to give detailed information concerning what is happening in other departments of the
University, not much more concerning the goings-on at other colleges, and none at all about topics not of a direct college nature.
Much of the news is stale by the time that it appears, and a portion of it is of interest only to certain men. It would be possible,
if the readers so desired, to publish more news of other Universities (or other departments of this University), but there has
been no articulate demand for such news.
The paper's editorial policy can be one of several varieties.
The editorials can shout "Hurrah"- and comment inanely upon
campus events, making an obsequious attempt to please everybody.
They can take issue with every question which lends itself to argument, and can invent a few besides. Or they can try to "mirror"
campus opinion—if there be such a thing. They can be a compromise between the first two policies, and, of course, they can be
a kind of conglomerate potpourri of all three.
They can attempt to evaluate the courses offered to the students, as has been done at Harvard. They can make an effort to
influence students in matters of a wider interest than pure "campus
topics." They can criticise activities and individuals in the campus
limelight—favorably or adversely. None of these have, to our
knowledge, been tried on this campus. The most weighty objection, it seems, is that the campus is so small that it is extremely
difficult (and undesirable, say some) to avoid the personal element
in conducting a campus newspaper. "
For the remainder of this year, we are inclined to evade the
issue, for it is too late to formulate a definite policy which could
bear fruit. To the extent that we sincerely desire to give the student body the type of newspaper that it wants (within limits—
financial and otherwise), we aim to please. Who knows that the
majority doesn't want any at all? We invite expressions of opinion on this subject, for we should like something to .think about
during the summer. Are we wasting much valuable time, or do
we or can we accomplish a certain amount of positive good?

Sigma Tau Delta and Phi Kappa Psi joined the ranks of the winners in the competition for the interfraternity baseball championship
The former fraternity won an exciting match from the Phi Gam's,
5-3, while the Phi Psi's have won
two games, by defeating the ,Beta's,
11-4; and the A. D.'s, 7-6.
.Kappa Sigma, also, not to be outdone, broke into the winning col
umn by beating the 0. K..0.'s, 5-4
Although Sigma Tau Delta scored four runs in the first inning of
a five inning game, it was only because of the relief pitching of Werner, who succeeded Driver in the final inning, that the Phi Gam's score
was kept down. The game was especially featured by the, work of
Werner, who proved to be a double threat man, his hitting being on
a par with his - pitching. McCauley,
who pitched for the losing team,
reached top form. after the first
inning, but the 'havoc wrought in
that session proved to be too great
a handicap.
Phi Psi's Win

In the struggle between the Beta's
and the Phi Psi's, baseball was
played amid wise-cracks, smoking
of cigarettes, errors, and amusing
situations. "Home Run" ,Brady,
after wonderful twirling for three
innings, in which he hit only three
batters, was relieved by Joe Richards. Averaging over three runs an
inning, the Phi Psi's did their best
to extend the four inning game to
darkness, and only failed by a matter of seconds. Campbell, the pitcher for the winners, held the losing
team scoreless until the last inning,
in which all the runs were made.
Brady received his title by knocking a screaming drive through the
legs of three fielders. In spite of
the score, the game proved to be
one of the most interesting of the
series.
Huey Pitches Well

In their game with the A. D.'s in
the second round, the Phi Psi's also
provided an interesting game. Huey,
who won his first gamt by striking
out twelve men, equaled his strikeout record, but lost a discouraging
game. The game which was planned to take five innings, lasted for
six sessions, as the score was tied
at the end of the- prescribed time.
Dukehart, a Phi Psi, who had caught
for the first few innings, came to
Campbell's rescue, and managed to
hold his rivals scoreless after the
fifth inning.
.The Phi Psi-A. D. game was the
opening clash in the second round
of competition.
Sigma Tau Delta tied with the
Phi Psis for the lead in the Interfraternity Baseball League by defeating Alpha Kappa Phi by the
score of 7-4 on Friday.

their rooms and frequently takes
iinner in the Dining Room. There
are now at the Dormitory, besides
the dog, two pigeons, one of
which fell down a chimney and
was toasted on all sides, several
peanut-eating squirrels, and an
abundance of rats.
* * •*
The effect of the coming final
examinations can be readily observed among the residents. The
bridge games in the Commons
Room are shorter. Even the
most active residents seem
shrouded in gloom. These are
trying times at the Dorm.
* * *
Practically all of the rooms at
the Dormitory have been leased
for next year. In spite of all the
complaints which are •heard during the year everyone signs up
again for the following year.
Many residents who have lived at
the Dormitory for two or more
years live in an entry which is
kept as exclusive as a fraternity
house. It is interesting to note
that there are cases at the Dormitory where residents have practically lived alongside of one another for two or three years without even casually speaking. Such
is the jolly good fellowship
among the residents in general.
* * *
A group of graduate students,
who were formerly thought to be
dignified, interrupted the silence
in the Dining Room during the
dinner hour with a boisterous outbreak of laughter. Their mirth
was caused by a cream-puff the
size of a pumpkin. The graduate
boys were making merry prob-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE ITER. MAY 24, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
Two foremost collegiate authoriities on astronomy are engaged in
an amusing controversy concerning
the date of the final extinction of
the sun's light. Enrique E. Trevine, president of the Mexican Astronomical Society, recently published a report in which he predicts
that the sun will have ceased to
shine in 2,000,000 years. Professor
Edmund S. Manson, head of the department of Astronomy at Ohio
University, has definitely repudiated
Trevine's .statement, assuring us to
have no fear as the sun is sure to
be good yet for at least ten trillion
years.
• * * .
Startling disclosures were recently revealed in another sequel to the
"ask me another" craze—this time
among theseniors at Princeton University. The 'Most amusing, perhaps, was the manner in which the
young men vented their ire against
the sons of fair Harvard. That institution was most ironically selected after Smith and _Vassar as the
most popular women's college.
• * *
Freshman hazing at Ohio State
University will, it appears, die a sudden and inglorious death with the
close of this year. President George
W. Rightmire recently issued the
following statement:"Any man who
is in any way connected with throwing a freshman in the lake will sever
his connection with the university."
It may here be explained that the
aforesaid procedure was the favorite method of the eager sophs to
put a quietus on the unruliness of
their traditional foes.
*

*

*

Too much discipline in the modern college is severely flayed in a
recent verdict rendered by Walter
L. Whittlesey, professor of Politics,
at Princeton University. Dr. Whittlesey makes the sweeping statement
that neither Jefferson, Franklin,
Lincoln, nor Cleveland would submit to the restraint which is placed
on the student of today, but would
probably have been forced from college because of their independence.
*
*
Films of forty students representing most of the large colleges and
universities of the country have recently been selected by executives of
the First National Pictures, Inc., to
go into the finals of the "movie contest" which is being conducted by
that concern. Ten men, selected in
these finals, will be given an eight
week try-out in the First National
Movie School. From among these
ten those students that display promise will be tendered a five year contract at $75 a week for the first six
months, this gradually increasing
until in the fifth year they will receive $750 per week. Well, boys,
that's another advantage of higher
education.

CAMBRIDGE Al\D BRISTOL TO STUDY HERE
of Hearst Trophy
Announcement has been made
that two recent graduates of British
universities awarded Commonwealth
Fund fellowships are planning to
study at Johns Hopkins next year
Dr. Thomas F. Hewer, of the
University of Bristol, and John
Dennis Ward, of Cambridge University, are the successful candidates
planning to study here.
Twenty - three Commonwealth
Fund fellowships, amounting to
$125,000, were awarded to honor
graduates of universities in Great
Britain and her colonies this year.
The fund was established in 1918 by
the late Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness
as a philanthropic foundation "for
the welfare of mankind." Two
years ago the Board of Directors of
the foundation adopted the plan for
the British fellowships in the belief
that additional facilities for British
University graduates to study and

travel in this country would foster
the development of international
development and good will.
Any of the twenty-six institutions
belonging to the Association of
American Universities may be selected by the successful candidate.
In addition to Dr. Hewer and Mr.
Ward, two other Commonwealth
fellows are studying at Hopkins.
Dr. Hewer will do research work
in bacteriology while Mr. Ward will
study the "Attitude of the United
State.s toward British Relations with
Central America, 1850-1860."
So far more Commonwealth students have selected Harvard than
any other university in this country.
Ten have gone there, eight have selected. Yale, the same number Columbia, and six Cornell. Twentysix are attending other universities
all over the country.
